sub_title: Classical Clarinetist based in the Netherlands
summary:
Growing up in New Zealand, I was interested in music from a very young age. At the age of 8, I started to play the clarinet, playing mainly classical music. My interest in different genres grew and I got the opportunity to explore jazz music in high school. This initiated a number of leadership opportunities, such as serving as their lead student ambassador of the arts around New Zealand. Wanting to explore more of the world and broaden my musical view, I did my Bachelor studies at the Elder Conservatorium of Music in Adelaide, Australia, with Dean Newcomb. I continued with Master studies with Roeland Hendrikx at Conservatorium Maastricht in the Netherlands where I currently reside.
During the years I have held many principal clarinet positions in various project symphony orchestras and academy orchestras. These orchestral experiences sharpened my social and leadership skills. I am a person that has a high curiosity about human interactions, the sciences and critical thinking. Fact-checking and authentic performance accuracy play a major role in how I think and rationalise my musical interpretations, whilst also including my own artistry to find balance - it is all of equal importance to me and my work. The pursuit to continuously develop and be a better version of myself to serve the activities I love the most has been because of these curiosities.
Music gives me great enjoyment. Whether by playing Mozart’s clarinet concerto, engaging with colleagues in orchestras and chamber groups, or listening to a Mahler symphony or a John Coltrane album, they all give me a sense of fulfilment in life. I am sure my talents and experience are well-suited for musical organisations and match the requirements of this highly challenging industry.
